reviews.review_title: Trois Couleurs: Bleu by Krzysztof Kieslowski
reviews.content: The theme of grief is one of the most complicated ones to elaborate, which is often explored through poetry and philosophy; they both usually give specific details, about what kind of meaning the grief might has. Some authors might describe the grief as the meaning of a burden, which must be lately thrown away, to feel the freedom again; while other authors might describe the grief as the meaning of something, which must be reflected about the mistakes committed by anyone, who try to search answers to see how far the grief will go. The auteur filmmaker Krzysztof Kieslowski has been interested, to explore this theme; to connect it with one of the three colors of the French flag, which is the blue one that represents freedom. In 1993 came out Trois Couleurs: Bleu by Krzysztof Kieslowski with Juliette Binoche and Benoît Régent. The movie's plot: After a tragic auto wreck, Julie (Juliette Binoche) is filled with grief in her soul, as she has been told her composer husband and her daughter died from the accident. Julie tries to free herself from the grief, by thrown everything away which is connected with her husband's work and other precious objects. She even tries to avoid to have interactions with anybody around, until her old friend Olivier (Benoît Régent) would bring her back to the reality; he would show her, how important it is to have interactions again. The movie shows to be visually captivating, to tell a complicated thoughtful theme, from the beginning to the end, without breaking the narration's rhythm. Even the movie has some missing essential details, to connect its themes with a specific context, which could have been reflected about one specific impactful event, which can be considered relevant with contemporary events. The production designer Claude Lenoir has build the different settings of the story, which the spaces are filled with specific objects and the colors, especially the blue one, to connect with the themes of the movie. Especially to connect with the feelings of the main character, as the spaces and the colors of the settings change, from being initially dark to lately become brighter. The cinematographer Slawomir Idziak has captured some shots to be fundamentally essential, in every camera movements as well as in every angle shots; the camera has been used in the most precise way, to be helped by the lighting, which creates some unique frames to be visually creative. The editor Jacques Witta has elaborated the narration's rhythm, which edits together different shots in the most precise way; some of the most essential frames, which have been edited together, create some of the most poetic sequences. The score by Zbigniew Preisner has been elaborated with musical notes, which describe the emotions of the main character and the themes of the movie, in the most precise way; the musical notes surprise the audience, in some of the most unexpected moments of the movie, by elevating the emotions of the sequences. Juliette Binoche did an excellent performance as Julie, a widow who tries to be free from the grief which is consuming her; once she finds a way to be free from the grief, she would find a way to understand how important it is to have the interaction again. Even there should have been more details about, if Julie has any kind of wishes, to have done more for her husband and her daughter, before the accident; some specific details on the things she hated at most about her husband, while she is suffering and tries to get rid off the grief; the specific details of the happiest memories Julie would lately regain, after she finds what she needed at most. Benoît Régent did a well done performance as Olivier, an old friend of Julie who would lately help her to find the most essential things she was searching to regain. Even there should have been more details about, if Olivier shares some memories he has on Julie's husband and if there are things he misses about the composer; the purposes Olivier wishes at most to have accomplished, but he regrets to have not done; if he has any kind of regrets to have not said to Julie, before she got married. Trois Couleurs: Bleu is one of the most important movies with unique poetic moments, even the movie did not used enough essential elements to be a complete story.

reviews.review_title: An elegant machinery of rhetoric doesn't make for a poem
reviews.content: I cannot be sure that Kieslowski cared much for the script of this film; otherwise he would not have made this 2-act film drawn out into the length of a 4-act. The symbols are there, elegantly shot perhaps, but not elegantly placed; the black screens and musical outbursts are overdone and obtrusive, to say the least. And when the widow, (shall we call her Ms. Blue? I don't remember her name) Ms. Blue, is given the cue for reflection (such as when waiting in the dark for an entire minute, deliberating on whether to open her apartment door to check on the remnants of a street fight), the actress "reflects" well -- but to what end? We get the feeling that Kieslowski is making a feature film from the pieces of a short film (what would be a fantastic short film!) and must slather a coat of cinematic, slow "art house" "reflective" paint over the missing pieces to hit a 80+ minute running time. Perhaps to make the film eligible for awards.It is a wonderful film, especially visually; unforgettable are the ultramarine swimming pool and a sugar cube absorbing coffee. But sugar cubes and swimming pools alone don't make for a feature film. The dramatic weight just isn't there, and the freshness of the visuals certainly don't mend the paucity.

The lead character was at the depths of despair when she lost her family, and she struggled to muddle through life afterward. Many vignettes of her life were shown; not one of them was particularly earth-shattering in itself, and each was represented by a piece of music. Some of her "life scenes" were very ordinary; other scenes showed us how hard it was for her just to make it through the day; others showed her experiencing some amount of happiness. At the end, all of the musical vignettes were brought together to create a wonderful symphony. The creator of this parable wanted to show us that each of our lives is a symphony in its own right, a wonderful compilation of our experiences, no matter how mundane or difficult each experience seems to be.

reviews.review_title: The first installment of the best trilogy ever created
reviews.content: "Blue" (along with "White" and "Red") is a cinematic masterpiece and one of (if not the) most innovative and powerful films of the 90s. Director-writer Krzysztof Kieslowski suggests an anti-climactic approach to a more visual interpretation of both physical and mental pain. How does one cope with loss of a loved one? How do we continue living if we're totally alone? Kieslowski forms a narrative around the characters in the story, and around their whole existence. Although the story is a deep focus of the heroine or protagonist, it shows the world both through and outside of her eyes.Juliette Binoche stars as Julie, a successful woman who has everything one would ever want, until one day when driving in a car with her family, the car crashes killing both her husband and daughter. After losing her family, Julie detaches herself from any memories, thoughts, and pain by giving up everything she's ever wanted, and starting a new life in an obscure area. Julie's deep passion always was and will be with music, and through her subconscious the music comes back and reminds her that she once was a happy woman.In the first five minutes of the movie you're completely hypnotized. It opens up with a closeup shot of a wheel from a car spinning on the street as the car drives. The cinematography sucks you in and almost foreshadows a more saddening mood, suggesting this road ends before the car reaches the destination. We're only shown the back of the characters in the car and we're left with very little to think about in terms of their psychology. Kieslowski knew exactly what he was doing by opening the scene in such a way. When the car crashes (in the most detailed and realistic crash scene I've ever seen), the movie cuts to a closeup of someone's eye in which we can see a man's reflection. We automatically know we are inside someone's head and that they are almost too tired to look at the man. Kieslowski's incredibly cinematic opening scene is just the beginning of a visually stunning and deep film.The eye is that of Julie's, who's lying in bed as the man tells her that her husband and her daughter are dead. We expect a big scene where the woman breaks down, smashing everything around her in a dramatic attempt to kill herself. But all we see is her shift her head and we know that she's suffering without having to show it. The idea of "Blue" is to question whether or not someone can start over and heal without going through the mourning process. We are lead to believe that Julie can, but something always comes back and reminds us that maybe we are wrong. Some scenes create this illusion by having the picture fade to black as we hear music then fades back to the picture. We all know that a technique in editing where fading to black is used to represent passage of time. But in this situation, it's nothing of the sort. Julie constantly blocks any memory from her mind, but the mind always pushes those memories out. Her husband was a composer and the music she suddenly hears is both a reflection of her past and a reminder to her that she is still alive.Every minute of the movie we are exposed to the pain that Julie is experiencing. This is more of a statement than it is an expression though, since Kieslowski uses magnificent techniques to draw out this emotion. In one scene, Julie is swimming in a pool (where she goes every night to let out her physical energy so that she doesn't explode with everything she's been keeping in), and her husband's music starts playing in her head. She pauses and allows herself to sway back into the pool, in the part of it that represents death. Juliette Binoche describes this as a form of a fetus who's not yet pushed into the real world.Kieslowski loves to pay attention to detail. Everything that's on the screen is a form of reality and a symbol of pain, suffering and isolation. For example, the scene in which Julie is in a restaurant drinking coffee exemplified just how much this woman is emotionally constricted. She hears music that she and her husband wrote, and she automatically shelters herself away from it, to disallow herself to have her memories come back. She quietly puts a cube into her coffee and watches the sugar turn brown. To some extent this is a perfect example of how not only Julie is withdrawn from life and others, but so are we, the audience.There's no doubt that this allegory is a masterpiece in film-making. Kieslowski often moves in and out of the frame with the camera, showing us a world that we're meant to see, instead of just placing an element in a frame and keeping it there to blatantly smack us with the message. To some, "Blue" is a masterpiece and to me it's also inspiration. Everything from its incredible cinematography to the haunting and memorable score, is flawless. Whether or not "Blue" is the least favorite of the trilogy, it comes in at my list (and many other's) as one of the best movies of all time.

This movie left me quite conflicted as it really is a strange film. On the one hand, like in typical art house style, the plot stagnates. While Juliette Binoches performance is outstanding in what ultimately is a one woman show, I cannot help but feel it peculiar that Julie's icy cold callousness and brooding can last quite so long into the film. Certain scenes like that of the mice in her apartment also feel as if they serve no purpose. Despite this, there is no doubt that the director is at the top of his game. The technical execution of this film is simply sublime- the camera acts almost as if it were a being with agency and purpose, every shot is pitch perfect. The directors use of the colour blue, through blue reflections, a blue foil, or some blue beads is both clever and artful. The music used is also superb, where the natural diegetic sounds are suddenly interrupted by stirring notes of the score for dramatic effect. These three techniques- the camera, the music and the acting- communicated information on emotions, motivations, and plot, whereas other films may rely solely on dialogue to do the same. Regardless, I must say the film sometimes leaves too much to be implied and too less to be explicitly communicated through dialogue, leaving some things more nebulous than I would have liked. It ought to be remembered that Three colours blue is, all being said, still an art film which might rely too much on "show, not tell" for a general movie audience.

reviews.review_title: A film about emotional liberty 🇫🇷 The first color of the France's flag
reviews.content: Three Colors: Blue (1993) is the first film of the Three Colors triptych followed by Three Colors: White (1994) and Three Colors: Red (1994). The three colors represents the French Flag which also consists of Blue, White and Red. At the same time, the each film represent the France's national motto of 'Liberty', 'Equality' and 'Fraternity' respectively. Besides, each film in the trilogy extensively uses the hues/color filter of it's title.In Three Colors: Blue, Julie is haunted by the death of her husband Patrice, a prominent composer, and her daughter Anna due to an accident. She was the only one survived and so, she does everything to free her from the haunted past. She removed her ties connecting to the past by moving to a flat in Paris as well as by selling off her property except for her daughter's blue beads/diamonds. However, she finds herself bonding with other humans connections.As Kieslowski stated, the film is about emotional liberty. Hence, she 'rebirth' in a new life where she got the freedom "to do anything she want which is nothing". She was free of her family responsibilities after the death of Patrice and Anna, but only to do nothing about building a new life. However, as things unfold, she finds herself connecting with other humans, mainly due to her kindness and generosity.To sum up, I recommend this work of art to anyone who is a fan of Psychological Dramas.

reviews.review_title: Reviews the three parts of "Three colours"
reviews.content: Apparently most people prefer Blue, I don't (I can see you coming and saying that's it's just my contradictory mind). Really, I found it beautiful, aesthetically and on the acting level (yes, I agree with everybody on the fact that Binoche is wonderful). But it was quite boring; especially it was so long to really start, but I guess it's how grieving is, long and boring. So people die, survivors survive: OK, life goes on, we know that. Therefore I started White with a bit of apprehension, and finally was really caught quickly. I will even dare saying it's somewhat Kusturician. Is it because it's mainly base in Eastern Europe that I have this feeling, or is Eastern European genuinely crazier and more surreal than us? I guess the fact that Eastern Europe had a lot to catch up with Western Europe at the time of the film allowed to use crazy ideas as importing a dead body from Russia to fake your own death. Apart that, I was really interested by this man who couldn't satisfy his wife as long as they were married, and could start doing it again as soon as he was supposed to be dead, meaning as soon as any commitment was impossible. Power, commitment and sexuality: such a millenary-old story. After this Red could have been a bit boring too, but it was very intriguing so it compensated the absence of surrealism. I just had a real difficulty to like Irène Jacob's character (Valentine): she's so naive and full of guilt, it's annoying, please shake her a bit! Which reminds me that I deny that any woman can be as Dominique (played by Julie Delpy) in White. Seriously, yes some divorces can be ugly, but it's rarely that intensely ugly. But I guess it's part of the surrealism of White. I think in fact which annoys me more in White is not in White but in Red. When you end up seeing the link between the three movies, you discover that Karol (the ex-impotent ex-husband of White) is finally back with her, and I find this so improbable: first she was in prison, and unless he reported himself as having faked his own death (in which case he would be now the one in prison, not on this boat), I can't see how she would have been released; second, even if she had been released otherwise, how could she be willing to go back to him after he planned a so big revenge? And more globally, what is this stupid link between the three films? The three couples (or will-be couples) happened to take the same boat, and worse, to be the only survivors of this boat's sinking. This is so happy-ended and unnecessary: I don't think the three stories needed to be linked more than by a random and meaningless meeting (when Julie in Blue steps into the courtroom where Karol and Dominique are divorcing for example, it's enough). Which by the way leads their meeting's number to twice: what is the probability of that, people not knowing each other encountering, and then when not living in the same country anymore, meeting again on the way to a third country? And plus what is the probability that they survive all together? In fact I was expecting them to die when they started speaking about the sinking on TV: I guess the probability that they die all together is not better, so maybe Kieslowski should have given up on linking them at the end. Because the link is already elsewhere: loneliness and death are all along the three movies. People die, people survive, people fake their death, people stop loving after the death of a loved one... People are in love but lonely: Julie is in love with a dead husband, Karol is in love with his ex-wife, Valentine is in love with a jealous long-distance boyfriend. People are together but lonely, more or less haunted by death. This is how I see the big theme. I can't see the meant-to-be "Freedom, Equality, Fraternity". OK, not really fair in fact: I can see some freedom in Blue, in how Julie chooses to deal her own way with her grief; I can see some fraternity in Red, in how Valentine and the old judge learn from each other; but I can't see any equality, neither in White, nor in the others (because I guess this three themes are not that simply distributed between the three movies). Anyway, I am sure this trilogy is far richer than this and that anybody would find something different in it.

Is escaping from suffering and grief the only way to return to the person you really are? Is the solution to destroy the remaining memories or become someone else? "Three Colors: Blue" discusses the battle with the deep sorrow of a woman who lost her husband and her only child in a traffic accident. The main idea is understood as follows; "We can overcome our sorrows but not by escaping".
The story begins with Julie losing her husband ,who was a famous composer, and her 5 years old daughter in a car accident. The accident is implied by the liquid dripping from the car, which appears in the first minute. During the accident, the camera pointed at the hitchhiker boy and we understood the accident from the sound that we heard. In the film, the sound often comes before the image. The use of sounds is so descriptive that we don't really need to see the image. When Julie opens her eyes at the hospital, we see the image as blurry and we immediately understand that we see through the character's point of view. We watch the majority of the film with the camera that follows Julie from behind. The director depicts the psychological situation of Julie in the scene with events such as the reflection of the spoon and the impact of the piano cover. The film focuses on one character and is wanted from us to look at the story through Julie's psychology. Julie's relationship with her mother, Olivier and neighbors supports the main idea and it reaches out to one conclusion; "Julie's search for a life without grief and sorrow". Julie was a woman with a successful and full life before. After that devastating event, she is looking for a new beginning and decides not to do anything to turn into a different person without any material concerns. She tried to disconnect Olivier. She didn't get the signature for the expulsion of the neighbor's apartment. She didn't give the signature for the expulsion of the neighbor from her apartment. Julie's "How can we break free from our Commitment" thoughts slowly deteriorates in her new life with the inability to forget her sorrows and pains. The blue color, which also gave the film its name, was used as a reminder of Julie's bitter memories in her past. Blue candy wrapper that her daughter threw out the car, a completely blue child's room, a blue ornament, blue reflections, a blue light pool illuminating the darkness of the night. Although she tore off the crystals of the lamp, which is the only item left in her daughter's room, then it can be seen that he always carries them and cannot throw them away. When she took the ornament and hung it to her new home, she couldn't touch them, and when her neighbor touched the ornament, it seems she got very uncomfortable with the background of non-diegetic music. The use of music in the film has great importance to explaining the situation of the character. The music, which is the harbinger of sadness and catastrophic beginning in the first minutes of the film, leaves its place for long periods of silence after the car accident. The scenes that we can hear the music playing in the mind of Julie while she following the notes of songs composed by her wife with her finger, are great examples of diegetic use of music. When the compositions that Julie throws it away are crushed, the music we hear from papers had also crushed, torn and destroyed, almost physically. The scene that Julie wakes up at night and witnesses the fight on the street is an example of the effective use of the sound. The man who gets beaten is running away and enters Julie's apartment. Although the camera is focused on Julie, we heard the man walk up the stairs, knocked on the door of the Julie and asked for help before he found by chasers, is the sequence that we understood from the sound that we heard. Impressive concertos often heard in the film, were high or low volume according to the intensity of emotion, also the use of blue colors were the dark or light color. Sometimes the screen gets full dark for a moment when experiencing excessive emotion intensity. This is a depiction of suicidal thoughts, crushing under heavy emotions, the inability to breathe, and perhaps the desire to die. We saw in the first scenes that our character tried to commit suicide and then gave up. The temporal order of the film was given in the plot very effectively. Olivier says he's been calling Julie for a month, and we get the elapsed time. Julie learns her wife's been cheating on her, and we're learning elased time from the woman's pregnancy. Julie is hearing a flute tune and let herself into music as she sits in a cafe, we can get the time that passes from the change in the shadow of the coffee cup. Cup is recorded with close-up technique as a non-diegetic element. With the small details hidden in the plot, it has been successfully accomplished. Julie plots refusal to cry from the beginning of the film, and tears shed when she overcomes it by the end of the day, a plot that sums up the whole story itself.
"Three Colors: Blue" is a film that seeks answers to these questions. It is one of the few that use the artistic aspect of cinema in such an effective, striking and understandable way at the same time. The perfect harmony of colors, sounds, camera angles and techniques in the film fits each others like a puzzle is appreciated. It is a film that keeps all kinds of emotions from beginning to the end.

reviews.review_title: A Film Which Gives the Term 'Art-House' a Bad Name.
reviews.content: I was dragooned into this one by my ex and a friend when it came out. Yes, it is a striking-looking film, but my personal reaction was total uninvolvement with Binoche's character despite the obviously tragic situation. One had the feeling of watching a particularly long-winded film equivalent of a colour Sunday supplement in which every mood was calculated to the Nth degree.One wonders how many people actually liked the film as opposed to thinking they should like a work deliberately aimed at a particular type of niche audience. As a whole, I found the film extremely tedious and have not been tempted in the slightest in seeing the films which followed on. Life is too short!

This film is one of the greatest comments on society to remember. I read a review of someone saying how this film does not express the liberty that Kieslowski states this film addresses. This is in part because this film is a negative comment on french society. Julie searches and searches for a way to liberate herself from society, however she fails to achieve her liberty because she realizes that without society she is nothing. Liberty is just a ideal that is impossible to achieve, but we try to reach it for the better of ourselves. Kieslowski did an amazing job on this film, creating the most stunning images. This film should be viewed on a quality sound system, turned all the way up so one can grasp how the music is a whole different story itself. I love this film dearly, and this is one of the greatest films of the 90s.

I also love when she is told that the lady downstairs is a whore and she should sign a petition to kick her out. Julie's response: "That's not my problem." Great Dialog.  R.I.P. K.K.

reviews.review_title: Kieslowski masterfully paints all of the colors, Blue, White and Red: see all three!
reviews.content: It is not only difficult to comment separately on the three parts of Kieslowski's trilogy, it seems obvious that the filmmaker wants us to do just the opposite:  view them in order, Blue, White, and Red, and consider them together as one complete work.  It is true they are distinct stories with distinct themes: liberty, equality, fraternity, and each them is developed with unique applications of intrigue and artistry.  They are each well worth seeing independently, but I believe they are best seen as one work.  Collectively, I would rate the trilogy as a 9; separately, I place each in my top ten for the years 1993 and 1994.Blue is the mood of a grieving woman who lost her husband and daughter in a rural car crash; it is the shadows playing on her face in a cold hospital room as she watches television coverage of the funeral; it is light shining into an empty room of her house.  Blue is the color of her dreams and memories, which she tries to erase after the tragedy, and of the liberty she seeks after the disappointing turn in her life.  Liberty is the ultimate theme here, corresponding to the three worded French motto, `Liberty, Equality, Fraternity.'  Of the three Color films, Blue is the most stunningly photographed and conceptualized.  The plot is almost secondary and the dialogue is sparse, which gives all the more emphasis on the visual and on the thematic.  With excellent acting by Juliette Binoche, this movie rates a 9.

Ticks all the European Film boxes: Death? Mourning? Intense love? Long lingering shots of faces? Moody lighting? Yes, yes, yes and yes.I was very engaged throughout, but writing this two days later I can't help but feel a bit unfulfilled about it all.I'm going to sound really up my own backside here but I think Martin Amis said something about stories having to be secondary to style now. His point, if I remember rightly (and maybe you shouldn't trust me on this) is that we've heard most stories before, so all we can do now is just try to tell them in ever more interesting ways. I think that's what he said, but try as I might to be an intellectual the brain isn't up to it frankly.This film has little in terms of twists and turns and plot points. But the simple tale is shown to you in such a way as to please you immensely. There are moments of two people talking that are lit so beautifully you want to grab other directors and say "why can't you make people look as absorbing as that? You haven't been *trying* have you? Stay behind after class." On the other side of the equation the DVD extras have a bit of the director telling you what he was trying to achieve with the close-up shots he was using and Binoche goes on about her painful dedication to her art and you sort of want to say "yeah, OK, chill out" and you feel like after they gave the interviews they might giggle behind our backs and laugh at how they made us all think it was all dreadfully clever.So, I would rate it above average, but I'm suspicious of it all and I'm not convinced this film is going to stay with me for long. However, I will see the rest of the trilogy and I wouldn't want this review to put anyone off renting it. Your eyes will come out of the experience feeling fulfilled.

reviews.review_title: Kieslowski : A true poet of cinema
reviews.content: Kieslowski was a true poetic filmmaker, a visual storyteller, one who believed in the intelligence of the audience. His three colors trilogy came at a point in his career when he was absolutely at the height of his powers. He had just made Dekalog and The Double Life of Veronique before and the three colors trilogy would be his last great works. The trilogy begins with blue, a story of a women who suffers a great tragedy and her grieving process. The film begins with an accident ,in which her famous composer husband and young daughter are killed in a car crash ,that she survives. The way in which she deals with her grief is unexpected and very sad. At first she thinks about taking her own life but can't go through with it, then she decides to try to erase all things and people that remind her of them. She attempts to liberate herself from her past but this turns out to be difficult, the unfinished song of her husband is always playing in her head, haunting her. She is also meets with a boy who witnessed the crash, meets a mistress of her husband and has a relationship with her husbands best friend. This is the type of film that takes you inside the mind of a character. She attempts to shut out the world and just exist but as she heals and realizes how important connections with people are, she grows and the ending is beautiful and hopeful. The movie is beautiful image after beautiful image and Juliette binoche's performance is one of the best I've ever seen, she's so understated, she says a lot with her face without speaking a word. Binoche somehow is able to convey several emotions with one look, she's really incredible. The movie is covered in the color blue, as you expect, the cinematography is beautiful as in all of Kieslowski's work, each film in the trilogy is shot by a different cinematographer and has a different look like the dekalog. What impresses me most about about Kieslowski's work is the way his story's unfold so unpredictable and also his camera placement,Their is so many impressive shots in this movie. Few directors instantly involve you in a story like Kieslowski, he drops you right in and where he takes you is always interesting, complex ,unexpected, and very rewatch able. You could watch blue again and again and pick up on new things each time. Blue is a excellent film and I highly recommend it and really all of Kieslowski's work is great, he was truly a great artist.

reviews.review_title: Wow! No explosions, yet still good.
reviews.content: According to my film 2 professor, this film is what is known as a character film. That means it shows the invisible, what is happening in the character's soul. OK, doesn't sound like my thing, but whatever, I was down for a free movie & getting out of a class or two. The movie starts with this little girl, focusing on her & her point of view, she gets in & out of a car, she sees the world as she rides in the car. As a side note, the audio wasn't working the 1st day, so the bass was very heavy. I think watching the movie this way, or at least the very beginning, helps to enhance to feeling the director chose to create of being underwater. Moving on. The camera focuses on a teenage boy sitting by the side of the road, & he watches the car drive by. He looks away. Off camera, we hear a crash. It was the car. Somehow, by not showing the actual crash, then showing the devastated car, the feeling the audience is able to experience is parrallel to that of any bystander: you hear a noise, expect it to be something mundane, and are filled with shock to realize that it is not. The rest of the movie focuses on the girl's mother, crushed to find that her husband & daughter died in the crash. At first she is self destructive, attempting suicide, having a loveless affair with an old friend, and dragging her knuckles along a stone wall until they tear & bleed. Later, she moves into an apartment, befriends her prostitute neighbor, and goes swimming. Her life is more in her control. Sadly, she finds that her husband had an affair, and the woman is now pregnant. She decided to give her husband's son their old house, and the movie ends with a sequence of everyone, showing how unhappy their lives are. The color blue appears throughout the movie, especially in a glass chandaleir whose importance is left to the viewers imagination.

reviews.review_title: A cerebral, poetic and misty experience
reviews.content: I don't think I can emphasise how much I adore world cinema, an innocent pleasure vindicated by the 1993 French film Three Colours: Blue. Starring Juliette Binoche, the film treats us to a dreamy snapshot into human remembrance and existence, forcing us to meditate on our own experiences of life. The intelligence and reverie that Three Colours: Blue exhibits should convince anyone how world cinema, dare I say it, is superior to most of the films produced by Hollywood these days.Although I hate the fact that years of English and Drama studies have hardwired my brain to view everything as symbolically as possible, I will admit that the emblems and symbols presented in the film are simply astounding. What is particularly enticing is director Krzysztof Kieślowski's ability to utilise symbols in not only objects and locations, but in film techniques as well. The smooth tripod movements and natural lighting emphasise our stability as observers of Julie's story. I don't intend to bore you with the multitude of symbols in this film, but I will mention perhaps one of the most memorable scenes in the film. As Julie swims through the ghostly blue waters of the pool, her introspection brings her to one of the core messages of the film - no matter how hard we try to suppress bad memories, we are inevitably confronted and challenged by our past.Now, allow me to examine the story without a gratuitous analysis of symbolism that could make me sound all too posh. I think the film has a strong opening that is laden with mystery and coldness that conveys how we are both observers and participants of the narrative. Julie's journey throughout Paris brought me back a feast of memories, ranging from the solitude within cafés, to inhaling the sights and sounds of Parisan streets, and ascending through the labyrinthine staircases of apartments. I should also mention that the relationship between the story and soundtrack cleverly represents the various psychological states of Julie, with the lonely piano phrases emphasising her isolation, while the pan-flute of the busker symbolises the mystery surrounding life. Although I applaud the filmmakers' exploration of issues such as solitude and suicide, the biggest let-down for me was the fact that the film had a slow pace despite its 94 minute runtime. However, if you consider yourself to be a patient movie goer, this shouldn't be an issue for you. Despite this small crack in the armour, I was impressed with the cerebral, poetic and misty experience of watching Three Colours: Blue, and I found it to be a good film to end the week with.

reviews.review_title: A little of the Paradise's Blue
reviews.content: It is very hard to comment on a film that was so intense. Three magic things happen: the photography (excellent, excellent), the music (eternity), and, of course, Juliette Binoche. The film is in first view a film about a memory. A memory that has to be forgotten (and thus it is by a revelation of the past). However we can read it as a metaphor of the present of Europe, arrested in its past, that has to be forgotten to have a full present as a united Europe (the music Concert for Europe is the proof). It has a poetic treatment and thus it has to be seen, with an astonishing look. (sorry about the english)

Many people say that "Three colors: Red" is the best of the series. In my opinion "Blue" is a lot better although I love all three films of this series. Juliette Binoche gives a stronger performance than Irène Jacob and July Delphy. Preisner's music is like the whole picture a wonderful and very deep discovery of human feelings. This is no film, it's a mysterious trip into strongest love! Go on this trip!

reviews.review_title: OK, OK, but what about grief for the daughter?
reviews.content: OK, OK, we get to see Julie struggle with her grief over her husband's death, as is evidenced by the music, the incomplete score, Olivier, the mistress, and so on, but what about the daughter???????Apart from the blue-gemstone-hanging-thing and the blue lollipop, there's almost nothing in the movie about what Julie thinks or feels concerning her daughter, and i'm a  bit puzzled by that.We get to see none of her daughter's friends, her living quarters, her daughter's interests, either at the beginning (when Julie is blocking everything out), or at the end (when she starts opening up to her grief)Are we to think that she was a detached mother to begin with, preoccupied with her husband's career and music?Maybe the scene with her killing the rat and the babies also points to the fact that Julie was a detached mother?And maybe her invitation of the pregnant mistress to come live in the house represents a coming-to-terms of Julie with her detachment as a mother, and thus she would want to make up for lost time?This movie leaves me with more questions than answers.

reviews.review_title: One of the most enchanting movies to date
reviews.content: All has been said and analyzed on this movie on this website. Thanks a lot for useful hints! All I can say and add is: it is inspiring, enchanting and deeply symbolic. Just terrific. I am sorry for the people who can not appreciate this movie as it is basically about humanity. Kieslowski changed and enriched my life, even though it might be marginally. Thank you K.K. and may your spirit be among us and in some upcoming director talents ;-)

reviews.review_title: The theme of this movie is fraternity, not liberty.
reviews.content: Of the trilogy, I like all three equally as well.  One of my friends found Blue to be tedious, I found it absorbing.  I disagree with those who think Blue represents liberty.  I agree with those few commentators who believe its theme is fraternity or brotherhood.  To me the movie is a depiction of the social recovery of the protagonist after the loss of her immediate family.  In my opinion Kieslowski is drawing a parallel to what happened in Europe in the aftermath of World War II.

This is very first impression based, so I may post another review afterwards, but after watching it, having not seen White or Red, I think this is an incredibly acted solid film. It reminded me of two films, Cronos, the debut feature from Guillermo Del Toro, and Amelie, the classic from Jean Pierre Jeunet. Blue and Cronos both have a very small scale, low budget, independent feeling about them, focused on one character's journey in a couple of different locations. It seemed like the opposite of Amelie in that they are about women in isolation, but in Blue the isolation is self imposed.
And that is the most interesting aspect of the film to me, this idea of running from your grief and locking yourself up as to avoid it. Juliette Binoche's performance is brilliant and captivating, completely cold, telling that where there once was feeling is now numb.
The interesting use of editing of fading to black at dramatic high points and kicking in the orchestral music was just that, "interesting". I'll know on a rewatch whether it works fully for me or not, but I appreciate it had a purpose, although partially distracting.
The naming and colouring of Blue, White, Red could become pretentious but in this film it was not subtle at all, although less distracting after a while. The film gets away with the colour because it really is entirely written around it, capturing the emotions of what blue can represent, beautiful but cold, enticing but distant. The theme of liberty seemed to me to be chastised by Krzysztof, this concept of it being not only a torturous existence to truly imbrace isolation, but also impossible in the world we live in.

reviews.review_title: A triumph of the human spirit...
reviews.content: This film has been a constant source of inspiration for me since seeing it five years ago.  Juliette Binoche turns in an amazing performance as Julie, a woman who loses her husband and young girl in an auto accident that she survives. Numbed, Julie reacts by giving up her material possessions and turning her back on humanity.  After starting life anew, however, she is forced to come to terms with and help the eccentric characters she meets (including the sex-show worker who is despised in Julie's building and the lawyer carrying her deceased husband's child).These characters force Julie to feel emotion and ambition again. Watching Julie finish the grand musical composition that her husband began is to see a triumph of the human spirit.  Despite the tragedy that made her want to ultimately withdraw from life, she brilliantly perseveres in the end. "Bleu" is a truly inspirational story.I highly recommend watching Binoche in "The English Patient" and "Damage", two films which further show-case her talent and beauty.

This film must be seen! (preferably in a darkened room , in the night, on your own) Visually one of the most beautiful films i have ever seen. The use of colour and imagery throughout was wonderful. I am astounded that the director has maintained that level of creativity throughout the film. The ingenious phraming of every shot i found brilliant and the way he managed to integrate all of the themes into this was again breathtaking. It is the story of a women's attempt to come to terms with the death of her family. However we are not only shown the relationships she has lost but how this has affected others. This story pulls you into the character as you genuinely care about the plight of the central character.This film changed my perspective on movie making.

reviews.review_title: yes its very good, but that music
reviews.content: Yes indeed, 'Blue' is a wonderful movie, containing some of the best film-making of the last decades or so. Binoche's role is as perfect as possible. Lighting is splendid, even though the use of filters is quite obvious. But that music! The score is an integral part of the story, or better, the essence of this film, and it is, in one word, horrible. I'm very sorry. This is very bad music. Like Mozart, as one reviewer thought? No way, Mozart is always light, and when he isn't, like in the requiem, he is profound. The score is neither. It's pretty personal, I know. But imagine what an Alban Berg-like score would bring to this movie. Or any twentieth-century informed music for that matter. Here we are stuck with music as boring as a Gorecki-symphony, endearing for a minute or two, but containing absolutely nothing.

reviews.review_title: More poignant today then when it was made
reviews.content: The existentialism remains the same but in light of the "Me Too" movement, the struggles of the protagonist have more meaning as we realize the equal rights movement of the 60s and 70s made gains but failed in dissembling a patriarchal culture. Binoche wrestles with her characters inner conflicts wonderfully and depicts desire and depression masterfully. The film has an intentional, slow pace that works as the pauses leave aching moments that quietly propel the story. It is to be "sipped like a fine wine," not gulped down.

One Sunday Morning I awoke on my friend's sofa, feeling a little groggy but, at the same time, pretty mellow.  I reached for the remote and channel surfed through the garbage until I came upon the opening credits  for "Blue" on Bravo.  I watched with pure intrigue for the next two hours. I emerged feeling as though I experienced a new High.The film is an amazing delight of visuals and sound complemented by the angelic glow of Binoche. Sit down one night or some early morning and view this brilliant film.  Perhaps by yourself and see if you experience what I did, for words cannot describe the feeling.

reviews.review_title: The best film of the trilogy
reviews.content: This is in my opinion by far the best of the 'trois couleurs' films. Far from any stereotypes it shows what is really going on in us. It leaves me literally breath- and speechless. It shows also the best performance of Juliette Binoche(and that means something!).If you like 'real' films about life then this is for you.A masterpiece.

Since I saw this movie in 1993, I've seen it again many times and appreciated it more every time I see it.  The one aspect of it that caught my attention first was it's dramatic use of music.  There's a distinct lack of atmospheric music, which becomes blaringly obvious when, during the grieving process, the lead character is suddenly hit with a severe sadness; something I find to be an accurate depiction. The overall feeling of the movie itself seems, to me, to be >like that of music: not forceful in it's attempt to provoke emotion, more of a subtle feeling of sharing in the human experience that is both painful and beautiful.

The baby skin is so red and thin that a stroke of light or wind could make it burst. Mama's desperation shows in her eyes and frantic manners when the next - where she quietly raises her brood - is suddenly uncovered. It's just a mouse family and yet their physical vulnerability and strong family ties draw us close to them. We pity their ordeal; we mimic their fear and pain. We are reminded that one day we were defenceless babies, too. For a few moments, we no longer distinguish between human and rodent feelings.Three Colours Blue is an acutely well-observed study of human solitude and broken homes. The protagonist Julie (Juliette Binoche) has just lost her family (husband and daughter) in a car accident. She is disheartened and despondent as she attempts to recreate her life. The encounter with the mouse family represents the newfound feeling of sympathy. She is unable to kill the mice because such barbarous act would represent the perpetuation of her own family disintegration.Finally, Julie borrows the neighbour's cat in order to carry out the murderous task. Her decision is contradictory but also liberating. She finally forgave herself for the death of her husband and daughter and decided to move on with her life. There should be no room for guilt and fear in our lives, Kiéslowski reminds us.

This is film making. This is a director who has inspired me as much as any great artist. Beautiful. Whenever I need affirmation in my belief that film making can be the greatest artform- combining all other arts- I look to this man's work as an inspiration. A master.

reviews.review_title: Beautiful visuals and a stunning score are even better when combined
reviews.content: For me, this movie has a very simple emotional conceit. The picture starts with a car crash, and we immediately learn that Julie has lost her daughter and husband. She attempts suicide, but can't bring herself to go through with it and instead decides to "liberate" herself from her grief in a different way: detachment. The conceit? Will Julie be able to maintain the detachment, or will she be cajoled (in a way) back into acknowledging the past?Of course, this is not the most revolutionary movie conceit, but I found it powerfully displayed and compellingly discussed. As the picture went on, I found myself increasingly wanting Julie to reject that false "liberty" and instead return to emotional connection. I certainly understand different perspectives and tastes, and I certainly agree the movie is very slow-paced, but I think to write off this conflict as "boring" or "pretension" is a bit unfair. I was unusually invested in this conflict, much more than in other pictures I've seen recently.But that does not make it a 10/10 movie for me. What does? Well, I think that the advantage movies have over books and art and music is the way they can combine visuals and sound into one single overwhelming experience. Kieslowski's choice is rather simple: the color blue, the fade cuts, the Preisner score... all of these form the "test" -- Julie's past slowly seeping into her present. This is the unique part of this movie. We're not told directly that her past is coming back by dialogue, but by the otherworldly forces only movies are capable of. "Blue" and its associated music becomes a character. Of course Kieslowski hits the viewer over the head with it, because this is not meant to be a secret. It seems to me that "Blue" is supposed to be that lifeboat calling for Julie to forsake her detachment and return to the emotional world.And given how cleverly Preisner manipulates motifs to tell this story in a heightened way, I think it's unreasonable (almost ludicrous) to declare such music "bad". I'd argue this is one of the best scores (even if entirely divorced from the visuals) of the past fifty years. And when combined? There are a number of scenes where I was absolutely immersed: the moment the music first enters when the reporter starts asking questions, the way the music contorts when thrown in the trash compactor, the collaborative music session where the screen blurs...As for the visuals? I won't even get into all of the magnificent shots Idziak is responsible for, as this review would become unreasonably long. Besides, the consensus from just about every review I've ever read on this seems to be the picture is beautifully shot.All of it sets the stage for an ending montage which absolutely levelled me. All of the different threads for a moment are brought together, the wonderful Preisner score combined in full for the first time, singing out some truly wonderful lyrics from Corinthians 13. And, after all this time, as her original contribution to the score starts to play, we see Julie cry, embrace the emotional grief she has been avoiding all this time. And then, in a truly inspired touch, as the hint of a smile starts to spread across Binoche's face in recognition that emotional connection is worth that hurdle...The screen cuts to overwhelming blue and the Van den Budemayr motif screams out in full. Julie's finale she appends to her husband's music says that the sorrowful past must be embraced. But by accepting that terrifying sadness, Julie can move forwards again. The decision to combine the narrative and musical depictions of the same idea is really quite a lovely one, and by the end it leaves me speechless with its breathtaking power.Yes, the narrative is rather simple, as is the theme. But honestly, I'll sacrifice intricate plotting and philosophical essays for a beautifully shot, stunningly scored, cleverly conceived picture every day of the week.

"Blue" is an emotional study of a woman trying to cope with the sudden loss of her husband and daughter.The pacing is moderate which is fine during the first hour, but since there is no tight storyline to follow, the last third is a bit strenuous.One of the strength of the movie is the unique use of music in connection with fade into black. I think its intention is to show how much music is inside the character of Juliette Binoche. Due to her mourning she is trying to suppress this music but it still finds its way to the surface.The movie contains some very impressive closeups, i.e. a feather on a blanket, a reflecting eye shot, a piece of sugar which is soaked up with coffee, etc . I think it underlines the inner conflicts and sadness of the protagonist, who is trying to shield herself from what is going on around her.The color blue is nicely present everywhere. In particular I enjoyed the exquisite scenes in the swimming pool.I was disappointed by a subplot with a young woman who is a neighbor and works in the red light district. I know that Kyszlowski didn't want to explain everything in his movies and leave room for interpretation. But here it seems to me that they had to take some scenes out of the movie which leaves this subplot underdeveloped.

reviews.review_title: Flawless Voyeurism Not For Casual Viewing
reviews.content: There is only one person I'm willing to see a film like this with because like me she is a sculptor. Like me she is also a bit of a voyeur. Bleu is not a film for casual viewing or the casual moviegoer. Because it is not a movie, it is a film.There are very few films I've ever seen that fall into the "flawless" category; On The Waterfront, Apocalypse Now, Sling Blade, American Beauty, Magnolia, Lost In Translation.This is one of those rare films that leave you stunned as the credits roll. It left me speechless. My friend and I sat in silence staring at the television until the tape reached the end and kicked into reverse to rewind.I've read the comments here and the one common complaint is that it didn't "go anywhere." Hollywood has left viewers without the ability to stray from their archaic, proven and profitable formula for movie success. Well, this is not a cheerful film. It doesn't have explosions, murder, mayhem, a handsome Leading Man and buxom but brainless Damsel In Distress. If you want all that, go watch Spiderman 2.If you want an experience, one about feeling, and to witness the beauty of an artist creating something more than a mindless romp from Once Upon A Time to They Lived Happily Ever After, you will never regret seeing and being Bleu. Don't watch this like a movie. Just feel what Julie feels.Easily in my top 10 of all time.
This is one of the best movies I have ever seen. It is in my personal top 10. Life ain't easy , but we have to keep on trying. I enjoy every single minute of it.

i am almost too nervous to comment on this work as i am an enthusiastic but amateur movie watcher! this is simply one of the best films i have ever seen. in the sense that it is a complete work, complex, layered, beautiful. every moment is considered, reduced, pure. that is the definition of art. i loved it. and i loved the anticipation of watching the next two, not least to find out how the remaining themes would be handled and relate to each other. but Blue remains my favourite. i don't often rate movies highly, but i cannot give it (and White and Red) anything but 10, i find no fault.advice: WATCH IT i know i will re-watch all 3 several times.

reviews.review_title: Exquisite Filmmaking! Kievlowski was a true Master
reviews.content: This film lingers with you for days. It is shot beautifully and possesses a haunting suspensful edge. Our voyeuristic desires are  satisfied when we're invited to enter the main character's psyche. Unlike Hichtcock, who was wonderful at manipulating our emotions with his contrived form of suspense. Kievlowski examines the intrigue and strangeness which exists in our plain reality. How truly fascinating is the seemingly ordinary human animal as seen through the eyes of a great filmmaker. Elengant, perplexing, thought provoking and ultimately liberating are the words to describe this film which much be watched as an event, not just another rental. The film also brings out the extraordinary talent of Juliette Binoche, in what I believe has been her best role to date. Don't miss it. Catch it with a special friend or loved one and some good vin rouge.

Truly, a masterpiece dealing with freedom and the ability an individual has to live totally free in the real world. A somehow slow-going movie, definitely unsuitable for action films fans, Blue is the touching story of a woman, whose family is killed in a car accident. However, she survives and decides to move on and tries to set herself free from her past, which proves a very difficult thing to do.The direction is wonderful and Juliette Binoche is absolutely terrific. What I really loved about this film, though, was was the heavenly classical music throughout. Juliette Binoche's husband was a composer in the film, and she also has a thing for it, so we get to listen to some beautiful pieces that classical music fans will enjoy very much. The music sets the perfect mood, and is so brilliant that points to the real meaning : freedom does not come by denying your surroundings and living anonymously. Freedom is achieved through doing what you feel like, through not turning your back on your nature. A free person is the person that does everything he likes doing. Which, in this case, is composing wonderful music.A must see film for all meaningful movie lovers.

Anyone who has ever experienced loss of the magnitude experienced by Julie, the central character in "Blue", will find in this film an piercingly accurate portrayal of the grieving process. This is a film about falling apart -- and slowly, painfully, learning to put the pieces back together, taking a single step into the world, and then another and another. This in itself would make it a remarkable film, but it goes even further. In addition to its emotional intensity and depth, it also has a strong plot, a magnificent soundtrack, wonderful characters and even humour (the mattress incident alone is worth the price of admission). And Juliette Binoche gives the performance of a lifetime, one that is human, raw and achingly sympathetic. What more could anyone possibly want?

Krzysztof Kieslowski's Bleu remains in my mind, one of the most brilliant films ever created. All aspects of the film: the writing, the acting, the cinematography are absolutely stunning. Binoche is wonderful playing Julie, a woman emotionally racked by the sudden and tragic deaths of her husband and young daughter. In an attempt to stifle her pain, Julie tries to kill her past (she sells her house and burns her personal belongings), but learns that not matter how hard she tries, she cannot destroy her past, her story. Here is where the cinematography is so breathtaking, as Julie crumbles under the emotional weight, the color blue infiltrates the film and consumes all aspects of the screen. Blue becomes the manifestation of her pain. Kieslowski demonstrates his strict attention to detail and his ability to create exigent art. We all have something we can learn from this film.

More than any other aesthetically pleasing movie I've seen, Blue succeeds in unifying the visual elements of the film into a single, cohesive theme. Juliette Binoche's subtle performance adds greatly to the film's statement about interconnectedness and the impossiblity of denying community, if only a community of two.

That movie was my closest moment to feel the pain of a loss. It made me think of my possible moves if I lost one of my relatives and had to move on without them. "Blue" was incredible.  Like Kubrick, Krzysztof Kieslowski uses symbolic images -- in the case of this "trilogy" it is very often colors as the titles would suggest.  Where Kubrick makes serious commentary about society and the civilized world, Kieslowski paints a picture of emotion and the human psyche -- many would argue a more daunting task.Truly the interpretation of this film is personal to the individual who watched it, but here's my take.  "Blue" was about one emotion, one state of mind:  the numbness we experience before grieving.  It is something that every human being who has suffered goes through, whether it is for just a few minutes or for a lifetime, as we feared Binoche's character would do. I felt the plot was a vehicle by which the director painted these emotions so vividly.Binoche's character suffered intensely and seemed numb to the world around her, but at the same time she also became more empathic and sensitive. She could not stand the thought of others having to suffer -- which was the case in her interaction with the prostitute-dancer and with the mice in her closet.  These many paradoxes in the human mind seem to be a running theme in this film (another is the closeness and anger she felt for the lawyer who carried her dead husband's child), and possibly his others (of which I have yet to see).To anyone who has a weak stomach for wrenching emotional imagery, stay away from this film. In the film, the powerful first part of a trilogy, the incredible strength and fortitude of a woman is shown in a profoundly moving way. Julie is already a deep character, but after the horrific accident where her husband and son were killed, we can see Julie pull herself together and gradually, through slowness and change, and realizing who her real friends are, find meaning in life again. The motifs of music and color throughout the film add so much to it, as the music is closely tied to the story line and the coloring and lighting of the film creates a specific mood for each scene that reflects Julie's own psyche and further allows viewers to enter into her perspective. Julie's late husband was a composer, and so the music in the film reflects his music and helps narrate the storyline and leads up to the moment when Julie makes the decision to team up with Olivier, her husband's friend, and complete her husband's unfinished piece.
The motif of color and lighting is significant, as it is a little unusual in revealing the car accident at the beginning. The lighting has a soft tone, with blues and greys and fog, rather than the usual harsh colors in car accident scenes. The crash is viewed from a distance, from the eyes of a random passer-by boy. This detail of softness, with the muted, misty colors, almost muffles the impact of such a tragedy which dictates the rest of the film. In other parts of the film, other colors signify more than just the typical setting. For example, the deep blue of the pool where Julie begins consistently swimming to ponder her husband's music, signifies both mourning, but also healing, with the richness of the blue mixed with the water. In the club where Lucille works, the bright reds and pinks exude sensuality, but the blurry focus in that scene brings the focus instead to what Julie discovers there when glancing at the TV in the office. The greens and browns of the apartment could be interpreted as the apartment being a place of growth, where Julie lives and begins to find herself again. Julie moves from a "blue" world (a world of grief, mourning, and numbness) to a living world full of vivacity, color, and music shared with the world and not just internalized. Furthermore, people begin to gather around her, people like Lucille and Olivier, who truly come to care about her. This human connection is essential, a stark difference from the first part of the film, where she is always alone, trying to live from day to day without support or connection from anyone.
The characters are important for Julie's transformation, too. Lucille's role in Julie's life represents an introduction to joy and liveliness. When Julie refuses to sign a petition to get Lucille evicted from the apartment building for being promiscuous, Lucille is eternally grateful for Julie's kindness, even though it was just an act of neutrality. Lucille's frank, outgoing, and mischievous nature helps draw out Julie, and when Lucille needs her help, Julie finds herself going far out of her comfort zone (to an adult club on the other side of town in the middle of the night), but this scene is a turning point for Julie. Being helped and being able to help another person begins to transform Julie from a complete recluse into half of a valuable female friendship. Furthermore, in this scene, she sees on the TV that Olivier has the manuscript for Julie's husband's unfinished piece, and it awakens another emotion in her, anger, that fuels her from a sedentary state into action. Olivier's somewhat presumptuous move here, in appropriating the manuscript, proves, like Lucille's character, that living quietly and without ant courage is unfulfilling, while taking some risks for a good purpose brings excitement and joy into one's life. Julie discovers this as she finally takes the step to help Olivier finish the manuscript.
I wasn't sure about the role of the mother in the story - it seemed like she was just there to show that Julie literally had no one to connect to, since her mother was senile and was unable to support her tragically widowed daughter. At the end of the film, however, the scene where the characters are listening to the finished piece, it shows the mother hearing it.
I did like the added plotline with the husband's mistress. It helped define a way for Julie to let go of the past a little more, although I do feel like in real life that interaction might have been a little more nuanced. The scene in the women's restroom where Julie confronts her is excellently done. As a viewer, you have no idea what Julie is going to do, and you can see on the face of the mistress that she recognizes Julie before she lets on. Julie's calm demeanor gives her more power here than the situation should, and that power carries her further into a sense of herself as an individual, which she needs to carry on living after such a loss.
Overall, the film was hauntingly beautiful, packed with meaning, and so thought provoking that one finds oneself mulling it over days after viewing.

Although Julie's spiritual transformation is the film's central focus, that metamorphosis isn't possible without Zbigniew Preisner's score. Like the balancing act of the camera and the performers, Preisner strikes a chord (if you'll excuse the pun) that resonates softly, initially, but as it drones on begins to echo the lingering antagonisms of consciousness that haunt the protagonist after her loss. Three colors: blue is the first part of Krzysztof Kieslowski's trilogy.The movie is about Julie (Juliette Binoche) who loses her husband and daughter in a tragic car accident. It's always nice to see films utilize colors in interesting ways, instead of the generic stuff in most big blockbusters. However, the use of blue is not exactly a gimmick, it never feels as if the filmmaker is trying to be profound.Blue is not a film where an awful lot of things happen. We see Julie go through her emotions in an effort to live on with the immense burden of sorrow that rests in almost every frame of the film. Julie is a stern and strong-willed character. At first, she comes off as almost too stoic and indifferent to everything; this is partly justified due to her having just lost her family. Yet throughout the film, we see her make connections with other people. She forges friendships and bonds with strangers and helps them along their journey. A very interesting juxtaposition is thus created between the way Julie represents herself and the way she acts.The film is full of moments that will stay in your mind long after the film is over. The film takes its time and lets these moments sit, this creates a slow pacing that fits and further enhances the film. The slow pace is never a problem since the film is only 90 minutes long. The cinematography and direction are both top notch like when Julie is told of the ascendant at the hospital, the doctor is reflected in her eye and we do not see her. Juliette Binoche delivered a performance for the history books with a powerful yet underplayed performance.Regimented to people who like:

Instead of saying which is the best and worst (though have often heard 'Red' cited best and 'White' the weakest, though all three films are generally very highly thought of) of Krzysztof Kieslowski's "Three Colours" trilogy, it will just be said that all three films in the trilogy are must-watches in their own way.

The first film in the trilogy 'Three Colours: Blue' serves as a very poignant exploration of grief and liberty (in the emotional sense), and to me it is one of the most moving and interesting depictions of grief and liberty in film. It is heavily symbolic, with its intricate use of music, the dominant use of the colour blue in the colour palette, its interesting use of fade outs (though actually different to their usual use, representative of time standing still rather than it passing or a scene conclusion), links to the main character's past (here the use of falling) and the bottle recycling, but not in an incoherent sense.

Visually, 'Three Colours: Blue' looks stunning. The whole film is shot with aesthetic grace and elegance and while the use of blue is dominant for symbolic reasons it is never gimmicky or cheap. Kieslowski's direction is thoughtful and never intrusive, and the intricate music score and the symbolic way it's utilised (representing Julie's struggles with isolation) is inspired, "Song for the Unification of Europe" is one of the most emotional tracks of music in any film seen by me recently.

Story-wise, 'Three Colours: Blue' challenges in a way but also always engages, mainly because of how movingly and intensely it deals with the tragic story of Julie and its themes of grief and liberty. The pacing is deliberate but never hits a dull spot.

One of 'Three Colours: Blue' is the astonishing performance from Juliette Binoche, an intensely affecting portrayal that ranks high up with her best performances. All the cast are fine, particularly Benoît Régent and Emmanuelle Riva, but in the acting stakes this is Binoche's film.

All in all, a beautiful, thought-provoking and moving film, and a wonderful start for a very interesting trilogy of films. 10/10 Bethany Cox

It is funny rewatching this film during a time where I am experiencing current loss in my life. It almost seems as if I'm grieving with our character Julie. Three Colors: Blue is easily a perfect film, filled with so much beauty in so much pain. Obviously, such as the title states, Kieslowski utilizes and plays with color as his main format. We humans have all felt "blue." Being one those people who look at the intricate details, I noticed and loved where the color blue appears in the tiniest of places. A blue trash bag in between two white ones when Julie throws her husband's sheet music in the garbage truck. Olivier's blue folder that makes an appearance in his hands in more the beginning of the film. Even in the dimmest of lighting, the color's presence is made known. Blue is everywhere because sadness follows us everywhere. Sadness is sadly a part of life.

Those two quotes written in the beginning of this review has significant impact, at least in my perspective. When we go into the stages of grief after tragedy, life stops and we cannot fathom recovery. We start to view life differently and distance ourselves from everyone and everything. We no longer want to experience the good things in life because we see the glass half empty; time is borrowed and nothing is forever, making it better to not get attached and care at all. Yet, we may not see it now, but we will overcome these extremely hard times, especially when we least expect it. We soon come back to ourselves, our want to live, our want to experience all of life's gifts, and our want to love.

Two tempting routes instantly manifest themselves for us after losing a loved one: wallowing in sadness forever and detaching oneself from life while being very much alive. Neither of them makes a logical sense. Logic aside, however, neither can spare us such an inexorable phase or get us out of it miraculously. Julie seems to have veered into the latter route in order to evade slipping down the abyss of the former. But grief must take its natural course, and suppressing it would result in truly dire circumstances at their worst scenario would be being imprisoned by depression, shrouding us metaphorically until a shroud takes its place quite literally.

"Now I have only one thing left to do: nothing. I don't want any belongings, any memories. No friends, no love. Those are all traps."

Kieślowski incessantly tries to save her from such fate and draw her back to life once again. His camera lingers in extreme close-ups on Juliette Binoche's features to draw out of them a smidgen of the sadness Julie does her utmost to bury inside herself. Later on as Julie keeps pushing grief away in her quest of severing herself from the past, she finds herself drawn back to it as memories surround her everywhere and no matter how hard she tries to escape them. When she returns back to her home for the first time after the accident that cost the lives of her husband (a renowned music composer) and her daughter, she asks the gardener if he has emptied the "blue" bedroom, which implies her trying of getting rid of the past. She goes upstairs only to find a "blue"-beaded chandelier, that's likely belonged to her daughter, hanging over her, just like her memories of her daughter. Julie's journey of liberating herself, in one sense, from her past life becomes impeded with reminders of her two dears she lost. Furthermore, Julie's incomplete grief begets anger and irritability that put her mental state at stake. And as memories relentlessly haunt her, she ends up surrendering to them, literally having her head under (blue)water. However, blue gradually begins to mutate its symbolic significance as liberation takes on a totally different definition in Julie's mind. It's here where Zbigniew Preisner's score blossoms into a salvaging tool. There's one scene, in particular, that I found fascinating where Julie and her husband's colleague trying to complete her husband's unfinished manuscript. The shot is pulled out of focus until it becomes almost utterly blurred, forcing the viewer to hear the music playing inside of their heads as they orchestrate parts of it. It's still a liberation of the past, but one of letting go of it while maintaining, nay cherishing its memories instead of eliminating them. A liberation that thrives on a catharsis for all of Julie's repressed painful feelings, bringing forth her deepest sobs and setting her free.

Cleverly shot with an overtly defined focus on visual elements to support (many would say supplant) its narrative, Kieślowski clearly had a vision in designing the shot along with cinematographer Idziak, and creates a protagonist in Julie that goes far beyond a pandering, simplistic 'sadness' to instead feel complex, real, often devastating. Her journey is at first despondent, then tentatively hopeful, and finally somewhat redemptive, but never is there a Hollywood moment of complete healing that would have ruined the sincerity of her labor. If you're feeling a bit down, I wouldn't reccomend watching it, because Blue is not going to help with a short-term solution. (4.5/5)

Julie, Juliette Binoche, loses her philandering composer husband and beloved daughter in a tragic car accident. She grieves and suffers in the aftermath as she is pursued by a young man who witnessed the crash and impulsively has sex with Olivier, Benoit Regent, who was one of her husband's friends. As her life continues to crumble around her she attempts self harm as a way to release emotion. One of her husband's, or possibly her own, uncompleted compositions haunts her and when she is finally able to complete it, we see her dragging her finger over the written scroll as a recurring motif, she can finally emotionally mourn her loved ones.

This is a film that I didn't really get, the only person that I have really mourned in my life is my grandfather and I was not particularly close to him. The whole thing felt like an exercise in misery punctuated by odd moments of sections of classical music playing while the camera cuts to black and then fades back in on the exact same shot. I wasn't exasperated or angered by my inability to understand the film or really connect it I want to watch the film again someday when I have more life experience.

I understand that my lack of comprehension of the film sort of invalidate me in my attempt to evaluate it but I still found elements of the film to appreciate and would urge those who have experienced grief to watch it.

The performance of Binoche was, as I expected, very good as her dark eyes convey an emptiness and a wounded sensibility that stands out amongst the relatively nonplussed figures around her.
